H0.text: Gravitational potential energy is the energy form that downhill skiers gain more of than the small initial kinetic energy, giving them little advantage from a running start.

H1.text: Gravitational kinetic energy is the energy form in which downhill skiers gain little advantage from a running start because their initial kinetic energy is small compared with the gain in gravitational kinetic energy.

H2.text: Chemical energy is the energy form that downhill skiers gain more from than their initial kinetic energy, which is why a running start gives little advantage.

H3.text: Thermal energy is the other energy form whose gain far exceeds the initial kinetic energy, so downhill skiers gain little advantage from a running start because the initial kinetic energy is small compared with the gain in thermal energy.

A4.text: Gravitational potential energy increases when two objects are brought further apart and is converted to kinetic energy as they are allowed to fall towards each other.

A5.text: Since the acceleration due to gravity is g=GM/R^2, this can be simplified to ΔU≈mgh.

A6.text: Another practical use is utilizing gravitational potential energy to descend (perhaps coast) downhill in transportation such as the descent of an automobile, truck, railroad train, bicycle, airplane, or fluid in a pipeline.

A7.text: Roller coasters are an entertaining way to utilize potential energy – chains are used to move a car up an incline (building up gravitational potential energy), to then have that energy converted into kinetic energy as it falls.
